title: Amber Rudd quits UK Cabinet over Johnson’s handling of Brexit
text:
Amber Rudd along with David Gauke and Greg Clark said that they are willing walk out of her government in order to stop the U.K. crashing out of the EU | Tolga Akman/AFP via Getty Images Amber Rudd quits UK Cabinet over Johnson’s handling of Brexit ‘I cannot stand by as good, loyal moderate Conservatives are expelled.’

Amber Rudd said Saturday she was resigning from the British Cabinet and quitting the Conservative Party because of how Boris Johnson is dealing with Brexit.

The secretary of state for work and pensions attacked Johnson's decision to kick out 21 senior Tories — including Winston Churchill's grandson Nicholas Soames, Rory Stewart and former chancellors Philip Hammond and Ken Clarke — after they voted against the government to push through legislation blocking a no-deal Brexit.

Rudd wrote on Twitter: “I have resigned from Cabinet and surrendered the Conservative whip. I cannot stand by as good, loyal moderate Conservatives are expelled."

She called the expulsions from the party "an attack on decency and democracy."

Rudd also told the Times she was "surprised, unfortunately, by the lack of work and preparation that is going into getting a deal with the European Union."

She added that "what I had expected to see was a huge government-centered effort to get a deal and at the moment there is a lot of working going on into no-deal and not enough into getting a deal."

On Sunday, Rudd told the BBC's Andrew Marr "it's like 80-90 percent of government time going into preparing for no-deal."

In April 2018, Rudd resigned as home secretary in Theresa May's government following allegations she had misled the public over her department’s targets to remove illegal immigrants.

In the wake of revelations that legal Caribbean migrants who moved to Britain decades ago — the so-called Windrush generation — were ordered to leave the country because they did not have the correct documentation, pressure mounted on the government over its policy to create a “hostile environment” for illegal immigrants.

Rudd claimed there was no government “target” to increase deportations of illegal immigrants. However the Guardian reported she had written to May about the department’s aspiration to increase “removals” by 10 percent. She came back into Cabinet when Johnson took over as PM.
